bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Joseph A. LePrince, February 8, 1925

div1.p: [Carter] refutes the statement of the Pasteur Commission that infective mosquitoes bite only at night. He will assist LePrince in setting up an experiment to prove this theory.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Joseph A. LePrince, February 8, 1925
div1.opener:
/LC.
2122 California St., N. W.,
, D. C.,
February 8, 1925.
Senior Sanitary Engineer J. A. LePrince,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Room 17 Court House Building,
Memphis, Tenn.
Dear LePrince:
div1.p:
You and Tarbett--an excellent man, by the way--are clearly work-
ing to check up statement of the Commission of the Pasteur Institute
(Marchoux: Simond and Salmbini) working at Rio, 1903-'05, that while
newly hatched Stegomyia bit in the day time, those of an age at which
they could be infective to men bit only at night. This statement, as
you know, was based upon the reported safety of people susceptible to
yellow fever in Rio in the day time and was supported by some observa-
tions they made on day and night biting of Stegomyia. The opinion had
been very generally held in the past, however, that yellow fever was
contracted only at night; as the above Committee formulated it: “It
(or “It maybe said” I forget the exact language
is probable that this disease is never contracted while the sun is
above the horizon.”

I have given this matter considerable thought and gotten some
data thereon: Here is some of the latter:

1/ Howard: Dyar and Knab analyze the observations made by the
Pasteur Commission and claim--I think rightly--that they do not jus-
tify the conclusions the Commission drew from them.

2/ Seidelin (in Yucatan) made some direct experiments with Ste-
gomyia from 15 days old & older that bit freely in the day time. The condi-
tions approached the natural, but the experiments were not extensive.

3/ Gordon and at Manaos, in 19 made experiments,
apparently very careful, well controlled and under natural conditions,
and they found that of the same bunch of mosquitoes double the number
of bites were recorded during one hour (from 12-1 or from 1-2) in day
light as were recorded during one hour (8-9 or from 9-10) at night.
These experiments, I think, may be held convincing.

4/ I reported 22 cases of yellow fever contracted during day light
(between 8 A. M. and 5 P. M.) in the Executive Building in Panama in
1905. Two night watchman, at least, (and doubtless they had visitors)
being in the building at night to furnish food if the mosquitoes pre-
ferred to bite at that time.

The above seem to me to prove that infective Stegomyia feed in the
day so as to be of sanitary importance. In addition I would say that
I have never known of a single instance of a town or a village in the
U. S. which allowed “day light communication” with an infected place es-
caping the infection of yellow fever. It is true that it was very gen-
erally explained by someone bringing back a handkerchief or something
of that sort from the infected town. Similarly, following the teaching
of Sir James Lind, (about 1791, and based on his experience with malaria
on the West African Coast) our Navy for many years allowed day light
communication with infected ports in the West Indies (St. Thomas es-
pecially). It was rare, however, that they escaped infection, very usu-
ally ascribed, however, to the eating of pineapples ashore. These last
two, of course, are without the scientific accuracy of the others, but
are just as true.

I am very glad that you have taken it up and I am giving Tarbett's
paper to Dr. Beeuwkes, going in charge of the Rockefeller work to West
Africa, especially because I see a 1/2 or maybe 1/4 belief in this ex-
ploded theory show out of all the English reports from that country, and
and
-3-
more from those of the French.

I would like to say here that this Pasteur Commission, above re-
ferred to, made more erroneous deductions from insufficient data than
ever did old Rush, who held that yellow fever was practically the same
as a marsh miasm, differing only from being due to animal instead of
vegetable decomposition, yet its conclusions are very generally accepted
as inspired by the Latins all over the world and this in spite of the
great French epidemiologists of the last Century--the greatest we have
ever had to study that disease, whose teaching their own countrymen ap-
parently have forgotten.

I will be very glad to consult with you, personally, if you come
to Washington, by writing if you do not, to devise experiments at once
feasible and convincing to check up the question of proportional night
and day feeding under natural conditions of Stegomyia over 14 days old,
together with the conditions which may influence it. I had never thought
of your time of the emergence of the insect by night or by day as affect-
ing the time of feeding, yet it might.

I have written an Epidemiology of Yellow Fever, in which there is,
naturally, some study of Stegomyia biology. It has been mimeographed
by the I. H. B. and sent out to all their field workers. A few insti-
tutions (The Hopkins School of Hygiene: Harvard etc.) have secured copies.
I presume you could get a copy for yourself through Ferrell, if not, I
can let you see mine, though I had rather hand it to you than send it.

Frankly, I count the question as settled as to the day feeding of
infective Stegomyia mosquitoes, but since you state that the Mexican
quarantine is based upon the contrary and I had to fight it off in Peru:
and Ecuador, further observations are justified, if they can be made
without interfering with other things.

Probably enough Beeuwkes will have to have independent observation made
made
-4-
upon this matter in West Africa, because there is, as you know, some-
times a regional difference in the biology of mosquitoes.

With best remembrances to yourself and any others of the malaria
men whom you happen to see, I remain
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General,
(On Waiting Orders).
